concepts.name: Ability Scores
concepts.description: The six abilities that define a character's physical and mental characteristics.

masteryLevels.criteria: Heard of the six ability scores
Assigned ability scores to a character
Can explain when each ability applies

concepts.explanation: Every creature has six abilities: Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma. These scores range from 3 to 20 for most adventurers, with 10-11 being the human average.
examples: A Fighter with high Strength hits harder with melee weapons
A Rogue with high Dexterity is better at sneaking and dodging
A Wizard with high Intelligence has more powerful spells
commonMistakes: Confusing ability scores with ability modifiers
Thinking you need high scores in all abilities

concepts.name: Ability Modifiers
concepts.description: The bonus or penalty derived from an ability score, used in most dice rolls.
concepts.explanation: Your modifier = (ability score - 10) ÷ 2, rounded down. A score of 10-11 gives +0, 14-15 gives +2, 18-19 gives +4.
examples: STR 16 → +3 modifier, added to melee attack and damage
DEX 8 → -1 modifier, subtracted from AC and initiative
commonMistakes: Adding the full ability score instead of the modifier
Forgetting to round down when calculating

concepts.name: The d20 Roll
concepts.description: The core mechanic of D&D: roll a d20, add modifiers, compare to a target number.

masteryLevels.criteria: Added a modifier to a d20 roll

concepts.explanation: Roll a d20, add your relevant modifier. If the total equals or exceeds the target number (DC for checks, AC for attacks), you succeed.
examples: Attack roll: d20 + 5 = 18 vs AC 15 → Hit!
Saving throw: d20 + 2 = 11 vs DC 13 → Failed
commonMistakes: Thinking natural 20 always succeeds on ability checks
Forgetting that you need to meet OR beat the target

concepts.name: Advantage & Disadvantage
concepts.description: Roll two d20s and take the higher (advantage) or lower (disadvantage) result.
concepts.explanation: Advantage: roll 2d20, use the higher. Disadvantage: roll 2d20, use the lower. They cancel each other out regardless of how many sources.
examples: Attacking a prone enemy in melee: advantage
Attacking while blinded: disadvantage
Hidden attacker: advantage on first attack
commonMistakes: Thinking multiple advantages stack
Forgetting that any disadvantage cancels any advantage

concepts.name: Proficiency Bonus
concepts.description: A bonus added when using skills, weapons, or saves you're proficient in.
concepts.explanation: Proficiency bonus starts at +2 at level 1 and increases as you level up. You add it to attack rolls with weapons you're proficient in, saving throws you're proficient in, and skill checks for skills you're proficient in.
examples: Level 1 Fighter with longsword: d20 + STR + 2 (proficiency)
Level 5 character: proficiency bonus is now +3
commonMistakes: Adding proficiency to damage rolls
Double-adding proficiency (it's already in spell save DC)

concepts.name: Attack Rolls
concepts.description: Rolling to hit a target in combat using d20 + modifiers vs AC.
concepts.explanation: Attack roll = d20 + ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient). Compare to target's AC. Natural 20 is a critical hit (auto-hit, double damage dice). Natural 1 is an auto-miss.
examples: Melee with sword: d20 + STR mod + proficiency
Ranged with bow: d20 + DEX mod + proficiency
Finesse weapon: choose STR or DEX
commonMistakes: Forgetting proficiency with weapons
Using wrong ability for weapon type

concepts.name: Damage Rolls
concepts.description: Rolling weapon or spell dice to determine damage dealt on a hit.
concepts.explanation: Damage = weapon dice + ability modifier (same as attack). Critical hits: roll damage dice twice, then add modifier once. Proficiency is NOT added to damage.
examples: Longsword hit: 1d8 + 3 (STR) = 7 damage
Critical with longsword: 2d8 + 3 = 12 damage
commonMistakes: Adding proficiency to damage
Doubling modifier on critical hits

concepts.name: Initiative
concepts.description: Determining turn order at the start of combat.

masteryLevels.criteria: Can track initiative for a group

concepts.explanation: When combat starts, everyone rolls d20 + DEX modifier. Higher results go first. If tied, players choose who goes first among themselves (or DM decides for monsters).
examples: Rogue with DEX 18 (+4): often acts early
DM: 'Roll initiative! Combat has begun!'
commonMistakes: Forgetting initiative is a DEX check
Re-rolling initiative every round (it's once per combat)

concepts.name: Action Economy
concepts.description: Understanding what you can do on your turn: Action, Bonus Action, Movement, Reaction.

masteryLevels.criteria: Used action + movement in a turn

concepts.explanation: Each turn you get: 1 Action (attack, cast spell, etc.), 1 Bonus Action (if you have abilities that use it), Movement (up to your speed), 1 Reaction (between turns, like opportunity attack), and free object interaction.
examples: Move 30 feet, Attack (action), Second Wind (bonus action)
Cast Healing Word (bonus action), then Attack (action)
commonMistakes: Trying to take two actions
Not using movement
Forgetting you have a bonus action

concepts.name: Hit Points
concepts.description: Your character's health and ability to withstand damage.

masteryLevels.criteria: Knows how max HP is calculated

concepts.explanation: Max HP = hit die max at level 1, then roll (or take average) each level, adding CON modifier each time. Current HP tracks damage taken. At 0 HP, you fall unconscious and make death saves.
examples: Level 1 Fighter: 10 (d10) + 3 (CON mod) = 13 HP
Taking 8 damage: 13 → 5 HP remaining
commonMistakes: Forgetting CON modifier at each level
Thinking 0 HP means instant death

concepts.name: Saving Throws
concepts.description: Rolls to resist or avoid harmful effects like spells and traps.

masteryLevels.criteria: Knows which saves they're proficient in

concepts.explanation: Saving throw = d20 + ability modifier + proficiency (if proficient). Classes grant proficiency in two saves. DEX saves avoid damage, CON saves resist poison/concentration, WIS saves resist mind control.
examples: Fireball: DEX save for half damage
Hold Person: WIS save or be paralyzed
commonMistakes: Confusing saving throws with ability checks
Forgetting you only have proficiency in 2 saves

concepts.name: Spell Slots
concepts.description: The resource that limits how many spells a caster can cast.

masteryLevels.criteria: Cast a spell using a slot

concepts.explanation: Leveled spells require a spell slot of that level or higher. Slots are finite and recover on long rests (or short rests for some classes). Cantrips don't use slots.
examples: Casting Cure Wounds (1st level) uses a 1st-level slot
Casting Cure Wounds with a 2nd-level slot heals more
commonMistakes: Thinking each spell has its own slots
Forgetting cantrips don't use slots

concepts.name: Concentration
concepts.description: Some spells require concentration to maintain their effects.
concepts.explanation: You can only concentrate on one spell at a time. Taking damage requires a CON save (DC 10 or half damage, whichever is higher) to maintain concentration. Casting another concentration spell ends the first.
examples: Bless requires concentration for 1 minute
Taking 20 damage: CON save DC 10 to keep Bless
commonMistakes: Stacking concentration spells
Forgetting to make concentration saves when damaged

concepts.name: Conditions
concepts.description: Status effects that alter creature capabilities (Prone, Stunned, etc.).
concepts.explanation: Conditions modify what a creature can do. Common ones: Prone (melee advantage/ranged disadvantage against you), Grappled (speed = 0), Restrained (disadvantage on attacks), Incapacitated (can't take actions).
examples: Prone: melee has advantage, ranged has disadvantage
Paralyzed: auto-crit if hit within 5 feet
commonMistakes: Forgetting conditions end at certain times
Not applying all effects of a condition

concepts.name: Skill Checks
concepts.description: Using abilities + skills to overcome non-combat challenges.

masteryLevels.criteria: Knows which skill to use when

concepts.explanation: Skill check = d20 + ability modifier + proficiency (if proficient in that skill). DC set by DM based on difficulty. Some skills can have expertise (double proficiency).
examples: Climb a wall: Athletics (STR) check
Detect a lie: Insight (WIS) check
Pick a lock: Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) or Thieves' Tools
commonMistakes: Asking to 'roll Perception' instead of describing intent
Thinking you can retry failed checks infinitely
